name: Roadside Ambush
prompt: In the Greenfold, where small villages hide big hungers, the road narrows between thorn and stone. A snap of brush—then men with patched mail and bright, hungry eyes step out with blades drawn. They don’t ask for coin. They ask how much you’re willing to bleed.

outcomes.title: Break Their Line
outcomes.desc: Meet violence with violence—hit hard enough that the rest lose heart.

success.text: You crash into them like a hammer into wet wood. The first bandit goes down with a sound that quiets the rest, and the survivors scatter into the brush. By the next village, someone is already telling the story with your name in the middle of it.

fail.text: You commit to the charge—and pay for it. A hidden blade finds the gap at your ribs, and the world turns sharp around the edges. They flee when you don’t fall, but you’ll carry the lesson in blood for weeks.

outcomes.title: Fight Dirty
outcomes.desc: Win fast—use whatever the road gives you and let morality limp behind.

success.text: You throw sand, pull a cloak, break a knee—anything that ends it before it begins. When the last one runs, you take what they took from others: a purse, a ring, a folded scrap with names on it. Profit tastes the same as guilt until someone recognizes you.

fail.text: Your trick goes wrong at the worst moment. Someone sees the ugly part—the knife in the back, the panic in the eyes—and the tale reaches the wrong ears. You leave the road alive, but with a shadow behind your name that can turn into chains.

outcomes.title: Bargain for Passage
outcomes.desc: Put your hands up, your voice steady, and make the violence feel expensive.

success.text: You speak like a person who will be missed. Coin changes hands with a practiced sigh, and the bandits let you go as if you’re merely another toll. It stings—but you keep your skin, and sometimes that’s the only victory the road offers.

fail.text: They laugh at your words and count your purse with their eyes. You pay more than you meant to, and the humiliation gnaws at you long after they’ve melted back into the brush. By the time you’re safe, you’re tired in a way sleep doesn’t quite fix.

outcomes.title: Hold the Rear, Save the Pack
outcomes.desc: Buy time. Keep them busy. Let what matters get away.

success.text: You don’t try to win—you try to last. You trade ground for seconds, and when you finally peel away, your pack is lighter but intact. The people who benefited from your stubbornness remember you as the one who didn’t run first.

fail.text: You hold too long. The straps tear, a bundle spills, and the bandits take what they can before you wrench free. You make it out, but your limbs feel hollow and your breath comes short—like your body spent itself to keep you upright.

name: Duel at Dawn
prompt: In the Greenfold, where small villages hide big hungers, a careless word becomes a careful threat. At first light, your rival waits in the dew-silver grass with witnesses who pretend they’re impartial. A duel is a story people tell forever—especially if you lose.

outcomes.title: Answer the Challenge
outcomes.desc: Stand in the open and let steel decide what words could not.

success.text: You step in on the first exchange and end the question cleanly. The witnesses exhale as one; no one wants a long duel when blood is real. By midday, your name carries a sharper edge in the mouths that speak it.

fail.text: Your rival is faster than their smile suggested. Pain blooms, hot and immediate, and the world narrows to keeping your feet under you. The witnesses don’t help—they just remember.

outcomes.title: Win with a Feint
outcomes.desc: Let them commit first—then punish the mistake.

success.text: You sell a stumble, draw their lunge, and answer with a cut that ends the performance. The onlookers clap because they don’t understand what they saw—only that you’re standing. Someone later pulls you aside and whispers that a certain witness is in your debt now.

fail.text: Your trick reads like cowardice the moment it falters. You take a shallow wound and a deeper insult as the witnesses murmur into their sleeves. You leave the field alive, but not unmarked by the morning.

outcomes.title: Dissect the Claim
outcomes.desc: Turn the duel into a debate—make their ‘honor’ look like theater.

success.text: You name the custom, the precedent, the exact clause that makes their challenge improper. The witnesses shift; the rival’s confidence cracks in public. A mediator steps in, and later someone important nods at you like you’ve proven yourself useful.

fail.text: You reach for law and find only air—your words turn clever and then desperate. The rival laughs, the witnesses smirk, and you feel the room decide what sort of person you are. Reputation doesn’t bleed, but it bruises easily.

outcomes.title: Refuse and Endure
outcomes.desc: Do not play their game. Accept the whispers and keep walking.

success.text: You don’t give them the scene they want. Some will call it weakness—others will call it restraint, and restraint travels farther than bravado. If your name has been dragged recently, this quiet refusal lets it breathe again.

fail.text: You refuse, and the story becomes theirs. By sundown, you’ve been painted as a coward by people who weren’t willing to stand where you stood. You can outlive the tale—but you can’t pretend it isn’t being told.

name: Siege Fire
prompt: In the Greenfold, where small villages hide big hungers, a town’s edge is on fire—roof-thatch and tar running like oil. Raiders move in the smoke, half seen and fully cruel. Someone has to impose order… or decide what’s worth saving.

outcomes.title: Lead a Sortie
outcomes.desc: Cut through the smoke, hit their flank, and buy the town a breath.

success.text: You rally a handful of the brave and the scared and turn them into a blade. The raiders don’t expect resistance that moves toward them, and they break. When the fire is finally beaten back, the town’s elders look at you like you’ve already been written into their records.

fail.text: Smoke eats your sight and screams eat your focus. You find the raiders—too late—and the clash is messy and close. You limp out with a wound that will heal, but not quickly and not kindly.

outcomes.title: Plan the Defenses
outcomes.desc: Buckets, barricades, rotations—turn panic into a pattern people can follow.

success.text: You point, assign, repeat—simple orders that stop people from freezing. Water lines form, alleys are blocked, and the raiders find fewer soft targets than they wanted. The town scrapes together spare provisions for you, and a few grateful faces remember your name.

fail.text: You try to build order out of terror and find that terror has its own logic. People ignore you, or misunderstand you, or run when you need them steady. By the time it’s over, you’re wrung out—mind and muscle both.

outcomes.title: Sabotage the Raiders
outcomes.desc: A knife in the dark, a rope cut, a cart overturned—quiet work with loud results.

success.text: You vanish into smoke and return with small disasters in your wake: a dropped lantern among their own wagons, a commander’s pouch missing, a signal horn smashed. The town is saved by a thousand little failures—most of them yours. You keep a piece of what you took, and a piece of what you learned.

fail.text: Your shadow-work is noticed at the worst moment. A raider’s hand clamps your wrist; a voice hisses your description to others. You escape, but you can feel the pursuit becoming organized—like someone wrote your name into a ledger meant for hunters.

outcomes.title: Hold Morale Together
outcomes.desc: Keep people moving. Keep them from turning on each other when fear runs out of targets.

success.text: You speak into the smoke like a bell—clear, steady, impossible to ignore. Hands stop shaking long enough to do what needs doing, and the worst impulses stay caged. When the morning comes, the town’s leaders treat you like a person whose voice can steer crowds.

fail.text: Your words land wrong—too late, too sharp, too much like command. Someone shouts back, someone else throws a punch, and the crowd decides you’re another problem to solve. You don’t lose your life, but you lose face, and face is a kind of currency.

name: Mercenary Offer
prompt: In Gilderhaven’s shipyards, where storms are politics and insurance is prayer, a mercenary captain sits easy by their cookfire, armor oiled and boots muddy. They offer you a contract with the smile of someone who has sold loyalty a hundred times and never once believed in it.

outcomes.title: Hire Them
outcomes.desc: Coin for blades—professional, immediate, and never truly free.

success.text: You speak terms, you speak payment, and the captain nods like a merchant closing a deal. Their soldiers fall in behind you with practiced quiet, and people notice you travel with teeth. The coin hurts to part with—but the respect it buys is real.

fail.text: You pay—and you realize too late what else you agreed to. A favor is mentioned like an afterthought, then repeated like a rule. The blades are yours for now, but you can feel the hook set behind the contract’s fine words.

outcomes.title: Train with Them
outcomes.desc: Put pride aside and learn the kind of skill that survives ugly fights.

success.text: You take bruises where lessons live. The mercenaries don’t flatter you—they correct you, again and again, until your stance stops lying. When you leave, you’re not famous, but you’re respected in the way fighters respect what holds up under pressure.

fail.text: Sparring turns rough when someone decides to ‘test’ you. You walk away with a minor injury and a sour taste in your mouth—like you paid in pain for a lesson you didn’t get to finish.

outcomes.title: Cheat the Captain
outcomes.desc: Promise payment you don’t intend to deliver—and keep your smile steady.

success.text: You let them believe you’re richer than you are and more backed than you’re willing to admit. The captain signs, the company moves, and you pocket what would’ve been their share. You also learn exactly how to lie to people who make lies for a living.

fail.text: The captain’s eyes don’t blink when you speak. They’ve heard your trick in three cities and two wars. You leave with your life because they allow it—but you can feel the danger of being remembered by professionals.

outcomes.title: Decline Politely
outcomes.desc: No deal, no debt—just distance and an exit before the offer sours.

success.text: You refuse without insult, and the captain respects the shape of your boundaries. Word travels that you can say ‘no’ without flinching, which is rarer than people admit. It’s a small thing—but small things accumulate.

fail.text: Your refusal lands like judgment. The captain’s smile thins, and a few nearby listeners decide you think you’re too good for honest work. It’s not a scandal—just a smear, and those are how reputations die.

name: Missing Purse
prompt: In Kestrelbank, where bridges and ledgers decide who eats, you reach for your coin and find only cloth. The crowd is thick, the air smells of spice and sweat, and someone nearby is suddenly walking very fast. In a city, theft is a language—do you answer it?

outcomes.title: Catch the Thief
outcomes.desc: Make the chase obvious. Make the grab undeniable.

success.text: You shove through the crowd, hook an arm, and slam the thief into a stall hard enough to rattle pots. Your purse hits the ground and a few extra coins spill out with it—someone else’s, maybe. The vendors cheer you like you’ve cleaned their street for a moment.

fail.text: You catch up—and a friend of the thief catches you. Something sharp glances off your shoulder in the press, and the crowd turns into a wall. You don’t lose your life, but you pay for the lesson with a sting that won’t quite fade.

outcomes.title: Spot the Trick
outcomes.desc: Don’t chase the runner. Watch who benefits from the distraction.

success.text: You trace the motion like a puzzle: the bump, the apology, the hand that lingered a heartbeat too long. You reclaim your purse—plus a glimpse of how the crew works, who signals whom, and where they vanish. That kind of knowledge spends well later.

fail.text: You’re sure you saw it… and you’re wrong. The crowd shifts, the moment passes, and you’re left with the cold fact of being lighter than you were. It’s only a little coin, but it feels like an insult you swallowed.

outcomes.title: Set a Bait
outcomes.desc: Make your purse an invitation—and your patience a trap.

success.text: You let the thief take it again, then close the circle with a nod to a stall-keeper and a foot in the right place. When you retrieve your coin, there’s more in the purse than before—either a ‘fee’ for the trouble or a gift to keep you quiet. You don’t ask which.

fail.text: Your trap looks like extortion when the wrong eyes notice. Someone shouts for guards, and suddenly you’re the one being pointed at. The thief melts away while your name starts to taste dangerous in other mouths.

outcomes.title: Appeal to the Crowd
outcomes.desc: Turn your loss into a performance—make theft unpopular for a minute.

success.text: You raise your voice and make the theft everyone’s concern: honor, safety, the kind of city people want to live in. The crowd shifts, a few hands grab at the runner, and your purse returns with an awkward apology attached. A local guard gives you a look that says you could be useful.

fail.text: You speak—and the crowd decides you’re simply noisy. Someone laughs, someone mimics you, and the thief is gone by the time your words find purchase. You’re left standing in the market with nothing but your pride to defend.

name: Whispered Allegation
prompt: In the Greenfold, where small villages hide big hungers, you hear it in the pauses between greetings: a rumor about you, polished and ready, spreading too quickly to be chance. Someone is feeding it—quietly, carefully—like a fire they want to look accidental.

outcomes.title: Confront the Source
outcomes.desc: Drag the whisper into daylight and make someone own it.

success.text: You corner the loudest mouth in front of people who matter and ask for names, dates, proof. They falter, and the room tastes their fear. The rumor doesn’t die—but it loses its teeth, and your poise becomes the story instead.

fail.text: You push too hard and look guilty doing it. The source smiles, the crowd leans in, and your anger becomes fuel for the tale. By evening, the rumor isn’t just a whisper—it’s a verdict people repeat like fact.

outcomes.title: Follow the Trail
outcomes.desc: Treat it like a puzzle: who started it, who repeats it, who profits.

success.text: You listen more than you speak. Patterns emerge: the same phrasing, the same pauses, the same careful omissions. By the time you’re done, you don’t just know the rumor—you know the hand that steered it, and you’ve put their name somewhere safe in your mind.

fail.text: You chase threads until they knot. Every lead becomes another conversation, another late walk, another sleepless hour. You learn very little—and pay for it in the heavy, dull fatigue of caring too much.

outcomes.title: Spread a Counter-Rumor
outcomes.desc: If they’re writing a story about you, pick up the pen and stain it.

success.text: You seed a sweeter lie in the right ears—one that flatters the listeners for believing it. The original rumor still exists, but now it has competition, and people love choosing which story makes them feel clever. In the noise, you pocket a useful morsel of leverage.

fail.text: Your counter-rumor spreads… with your fingerprints on it. Someone notices how eagerly you’ve tried to redirect the flow, and they decide you must have something to hide. The scandal becomes less specific and more damaging.

outcomes.title: Say Nothing
outcomes.desc: Let the lie starve. Keep your face calm until the city finds a new meal.

success.text: You refuse to chase shadows. Without your reaction, the rumor loses its sport, and the gossips drift to fresher prey. For a little while, you move through conversation like stone through water—untouched, unbothered.

fail.text: Silence reads as confession to the sort of people who enjoy certainty. The rumor thickens while you hold still, and you feel your standing slip in small, invisible ways. You didn’t fight it—and the city decided that meant it won.

name: Counterfeit Seal
prompt: In Kestrelbank, where bridges and ledgers decide who eats, a packet of papers crosses your hands—clean vellum, expensive ink, and a seal that is almost perfect. Almost. Whoever made it understands authority well enough to imitate it, and that makes the forgery more dangerous than any clumsy lie. If you expose it, you’ll anger someone. If you use it, you’ll become someone worth hunting. If you study it… you may find yourself thinking like its maker.

outcomes.title: Report It to a Proper Clerk
outcomes.desc: Bring the fraud into daylight, where liars hate to stand.

success.text: You present the flaw with calm certainty: the pressure line, the wax blend, the angle of the crest. The clerk pales, then nods—this matters. You’ve made yourself useful, and people who keep ledgers remember useful names.

fail.text: Your warning lands poorly. Someone in the office goes still, too still, and later you feel eyes on you in the street. The counterfeiters don’t know what you know—only that you know *something*.

outcomes.title: Use the Seal Once
outcomes.desc: A false mark opens real doors—briefly.

success.text: You choose a door that will not ask questions and a moment when no one wants to be the one who delays an ‘official’ matter. The seal does its work. People step aside. You leave with tangible advantage—and a fresh appreciation for how thin legitimacy can be.

fail.text: The wrong person examines the wax. Their eyes narrow. Their smile becomes a blade. You’re not simply refused—you’re *remembered*, and remembered by the kind of people who keep chains ready.

outcomes.title: Study the Hand Behind It
outcomes.desc: Learn the lie well enough to recognize its siblings.

success.text: You take your time—fingerprints in wax, micro-scratches on the stamp, tiny habits a craftsman can’t help leaving behind. It’s a language of fraud, and you’ve learned a few words of it.

fail.text: Hours pass in tense concentration. In the end you’ve gained only suspicion and a headache, and you feel as though the document has stared back at you the whole time.

outcomes.title: Burn It Quietly
outcomes.desc: Destroy the evidence before it destroys you.

success.text: You feed the papers to flame until only ash remains. You’ve chosen caution over leverage. For once, that restraint feels like a kind of strength.

fail.text: Someone sees the smoke at the wrong time. No accusation is spoken aloud, but you feel the shift: a small, private attention settling onto you like dust.

name: Backroom Auction
prompt: In Marrowgate, where tolls are tradition and corruption is a local craft, behind a shuttered door, a dozen quiet people pretend they’re strangers. Forbidden goods sit on a cloth like offerings: a reliquary shard, a sealed letter, a knife that looks too honest. Every bid is a confession in a different accent.

outcomes.title: Bid for the Prize
outcomes.desc: Spend coin to buy leverage—and accept that the room will remember your face.

success.text: You bid like you belong there, and people believe you because you sound like you do. The prize comes wrapped in plain cloth, heavier than it should be, and a few eyes follow it all the way to your hands. You leave poorer in coin, richer in leverage—and visible in the wrong circles.

fail.text: You pay—and then someone laughs, too softly, and the bidding turns against you like a tide. Your coin is taken, your pride is dented, and when you stand to leave, the room’s silence feels judgmental. You didn’t just lose money—you lost composure.

outcomes.title: Steal It
outcomes.desc: Take what you want and trust your legs to solve the rest.

success.text: A candle gutters at the right moment, and you become a rumor instead of a person. The prize slips into your coat with the clean satisfaction of theft done well. When you finally stop running, you realize you didn’t just steal an object—you stole someone’s plan.

fail.text: Your hand closes on the prize—and another hand closes on your wrist like a shackle. The door slams, voices sharpen, and you bolt through a side passage with your heart in your throat. You escape, but now there’s a price attached to you.

outcomes.title: Identify the Buyers
outcomes.desc: Don’t chase objects. Chase names.

success.text: You watch hands and rings, note who nods to whom, count which bids are signals rather than prices. The goods are less important than the network buying them. You leave with a map in your head and two names you can spend when you need to.

fail.text: Everyone in the room is practiced at looking like no one. You chase false tells until your thoughts fray, and you realize you’ve learned only that you’re outmatched here. You leave feeling tired—and watched for trying.

outcomes.title: Walk Away
outcomes.desc: Leave your hands clean, your purse closed, and your curiosity unsatisfied.

success.text: You take one last look, then decide the cost isn’t worth the story. No one stops you; no one needs to. You leave with your conscience intact and your future unentangled—at least in this particular knot.

fail.text: You turn to go—and a familiar face notices you noticing. Later, a door closes more slowly for you, a conversation ends when you approach. You kept your hands clean, but the room still managed to mark you as ‘involved.’

name: Petition Day
prompt: In High Valewyr’s court, where etiquette is a blade with a velvet hilt, the hall is packed with people who have practiced their suffering in front of mirrors. A farmer with cracked hands. A widow with a folded deed. A minor lord with a voice trained to sound inevitable. The steward calls names, the crowd mutters, and somewhere in it all—someone wants your favor. Whatever you do, someone else will call it corruption.

outcomes.title: Back the Commoners
outcomes.desc: Side with the small voices, even if the large ones take note.

success.text: You speak plainly, without flourish, and the room understands that you mean it. The commoners don’t cheer—this isn’t a play—but their posture changes, and so do a few guarded looks from the benches up front. You leave the hall with a better name and a little more weight behind your words.

fail.text: Your support lands awkwardly—too loud, too naïve, too easy to caricature. A noble laughs at the wrong moment and the room follows their lead. By dusk the story isn’t that you tried to help, but that you didn’t understand how help is supposed to look.

outcomes.title: Back the Lords
outcomes.desc: Choose stability and patronage over fairness and applause.

success.text: You align yourself with power as if it were simple prudence. The lords nod; the steward relaxes; the hall moves on. Someone later presses a ‘gift’ into your hand with the same casual confidence they use for commands.

fail.text: You pick the powerful side—and still manage to offend them, which is a special kind of mistake. The petitioners glare, the lords bristle, and you leave having bought no one’s gratitude. Court remembers wasted favors like it remembers spilled wine: immediately and with annoyance.

outcomes.title: Investigate the Claim
outcomes.desc: Slow the rush to judgment and look for what the room is hiding from itself.

success.text: You ask the questions that make liars swallow. Dates. Witnesses. Ledgers. The truth that emerges is messier than either side wants, and that makes it valuable. A clerk slips you a small purse for ‘your time’—and a quiet detail that will matter later.

fail.text: You pull threads until the whole hearing snarls. People get impatient with complexity, especially when it threatens their preferred outcome. You leave with ink on your fingers, a headache behind the eyes, and the sense that you’ve worked hard to make everyone dislike you equally.

outcomes.title: Profit Quietly
outcomes.desc: While everyone argues in public, you make your arrangements in private.

success.text: You sell little promises to people too angry to notice they’re being handled. A coin here, a coin there—nothing dramatic, nothing traceable. When the hall finally empties, your purse is heavier and your conscience is… negotiable.

fail.text: You try to skim from the chaos and someone catches the shape of your hands moving. A rumor begins in the same breath as your ‘deal,’ and it spreads faster than you can deny it. You keep some of the coin, but lose something more expensive: standing.

name: Feast of Favors
prompt: In High Valewyr’s court, where etiquette is a blade with a velvet hilt, the table groans with roasted meat and sugared fruit, but the real weight in the room is invisible. Every toast is a trade. Every laugh is an audition. Servants drift like ghosts, collecting scraps and secrets with the same practiced care.

outcomes.title: Toast the Host
outcomes.desc: Give the room a story where you play your part perfectly.

success.text: You rise at the right moment, neither too eager nor too late, and your words land like a well-placed hand on a shoulder. The host smiles—genuinely, or at least convincingly—and you feel doors click open somewhere behind polite eyes.

fail.text: You misjudge the tone—praise that sounds like mockery, warmth that sounds like grasping. The host’s smile holds, but the room notices the crack. Later, conversations bend away from you as if by instinct.

outcomes.title: Listen for Leverage
outcomes.desc: Eat little, listen much, and collect what others forget they’ve said.

success.text: You drift from cluster to cluster, letting other people’s vanity do the work. A careless admission. A name spoken with disdain. A promise that shouldn’t have been made. By the time dessert is served, you’ve already banked the evening’s real profits.

fail.text: You lean in one time too many, ask one question too sharp, and someone’s gaze lingers on you like a needle finding fabric. You still hear things—but now you also feel it: you’ve been noticed, and not with admiration.

outcomes.title: Win the Debate
outcomes.desc: Outshine a rival in the open, where everyone can pretend it’s about ‘ideas.’

success.text: You take their argument apart with a smile, leaving them nowhere to stand without looking foolish. The room rewards you with laughter and attention—the only applause court allows itself. Your rival goes quiet, and quiet at a feast is a kind of defeat.

fail.text: You reach for a clever point and find the floor drops away. The rival twists your words, the room follows the spin, and suddenly you’re the joke. It’s not ruin—but it is embarrassment that will be remembered the next time you speak.

outcomes.title: Keep Your Limits
outcomes.desc: Refuse the extra cups, the dares, the ‘one more’ that makes people sloppy.

success.text: You sip, you pace yourself, you step away when the room grows loud. While others spend themselves on bravado, you keep your mind intact. If fatigue has been clinging to you, the discipline shakes it loose—at least a little.

fail.text: You try to hold the line and still get dragged into the night’s current. Too many cups, too many conversations, too many little performances. By the time you escape, you’re drained to the bone—exactly the state in which people make mistakes.

name: Herald's Challenge
prompt: In High Valewyr’s court, where etiquette is a blade with a velvet hilt, a herald’s voice rings out over the square: contests of arms, riddles, and wagers. People gather for spectacle, but the true audience is the one that counts reputations like coin. Win, and you rise. Lose, and you become a story someone else tells.

outcomes.title: Enter the Lists
outcomes.desc: Put your body where your pride is and trust your steel under the eyes of the crowd.

success.text: You take a hit that would rattle lesser bones and answer with one that ends the bout cleanly. The crowd roars, the herald repeats your name, and a shower of small bets turns into real money in your hands. For a moment, you are exactly the sort of person songs begin with.

fail.text: You step into the lists and learn that glory is sharp on both sides. Something goes wrong—a footing, a timing, a breath—and pain explodes through you. The crowd’s cheer turns uncertain as you’re helped away, and the day’s lesson sinks in: spectacle doesn’t care if you limp afterward.

outcomes.title: Solve the Riddle
outcomes.desc: Win without bruises—make your mind the weapon everyone watches.

success.text: You listen, you pause, you let the crowd get impatient—and then you answer as if the solution was always obvious. The herald blinks, impressed despite themselves. A bystander murmurs a private detail about the riddle’s sponsor, as if rewarding you for being clever enough to deserve it.

fail.text: You commit to an answer and feel the moment it turns wrong in your mouth. The crowd laughs—not cruelly, but enough. You bow, because that’s what one does, and you walk away with the faint ache of being seen and found wanting.

outcomes.title: Sponsor a Contender
outcomes.desc: Put coin behind someone stronger and let their victory become your investment.

success.text: You choose well, and you speak to the contender in a way that makes them believe you’re the start of a better future. They win, and they point at you when the crowd asks who backed them. The coin is spent, but it returns as something rarer: gratitude with witnesses.

fail.text: Your sponsored champion loses quickly and publicly. The crowd forgets them by the next bout—but not your coin changing hands for nothing. The loss pinches hard enough that you feel the edge of debt start to creep into your days.

outcomes.title: Fix the Wager
outcomes.desc: Make sure chance favors you—by replacing chance with planning.

success.text: You whisper to the right person and the ‘right person’ whispers to someone with a loose grip on integrity. The bout goes exactly as you needed it to. Your winnings are heavy and satisfying—right up until you remember that heavy things are harder to hide.

fail.text: The fix breaks in the open. A shout, a finger pointed, a guard stepping forward with the enthusiasm of someone who loves simple villains. You slip away, but not cleanly—your name gets dirt on it, and the law gets curious.

name: Tax Collector's Audit
prompt: At Ashqar’s oasis court, where shade and law trade places by noon, a clerk arrives with ledgers and a practiced frown, accompanied by a guard who looks bored in the way only armed men can. They lay stamped papers on your table as if setting down a verdict. The numbers are ‘what’s due.’ The real question is what else they think they can take.

outcomes.title: Pay What’s Due
outcomes.desc: Swallow the bitterness, count the coin, and be done with it.

success.text: You pay without argument. The clerk’s disappointment is visible for a heartbeat—they hoped for leverage, not compliance. They stamp the ledger, nod once, and leave you with nothing but a lighter purse and the rare peace of a closed account.

fail.text: You try to pay and discover you’ve miscounted what you can afford—pride included. The clerk’s smile is small and satisfied as they add a ‘processing fee’ and a note that will follow you. It’s not ruin, but it is the beginning of being chased by numbers.

outcomes.title: Argue Exemptions
outcomes.desc: Find a lawful crack in their certainty and wedge it open with ink.

success.text: You cite the right charter, the right season, the right clause that makes their demand less absolute than they’d like. The clerk grudgingly adjusts the total and—more importantly—marks you as someone who reads. That alone buys you a sliver of respect in bureaucratic circles.

fail.text: They let you speak, then dismantle your argument with the patience of someone paid by the hour. By the end, the demand feels heavier, not lighter. The clerk leaves pleased, and you’re left with an obligation you can’t wriggle out of with words.

outcomes.title: Bribe the Clerk
outcomes.desc: Turn public duty into private profit—quietly, efficiently, and without witnesses.

success.text: You slide coin like it’s accidental, and the clerk’s hand covers it like it’s natural. Their pen scratches a kinder story into the ledger. As they leave, you realize you’ve bought more than relief—you’ve bought a person who can be reminded of what they took.

fail.text: The clerk goes stiff. The guard’s boredom evaporates. Suddenly you’re not a citizen with a problem—you’re a criminal offering proof in broad daylight. You talk your way out of immediate chains, but you can feel the law’s attention turn toward you.

outcomes.title: Rally the Town
outcomes.desc: Make the audit costly by turning it into a public scene the clerk can’t control.

success.text: You don’t shout—shouting is for the powerless. You speak, and people gather, and the clerk finds themselves explaining numbers to faces that look angry and hungry. They retreat into procedure and paperwork, and in doing so, they give you a win with witnesses.

fail.text: The crowd doesn’t follow your lead; it follows its own frustration. The clerk stands back and lets the mob make you look like the instigator. When guards arrive, the simplest story wins: you caused trouble. Your name takes the bruise.

name: River Crossing
prompt: In Marrowgate, where tolls are tradition and corruption is a local craft, the river runs high and fast, carrying branches like thrown spears. The far bank is close enough to want, far enough to punish impatience. There’s a ferryman watching from the reeds—if he’s real, and if he’s honest.

outcomes.title: Force the Ford
outcomes.desc: Wade in and trust your strength to out-argue the current.

success.text: You hit the water like you mean it. Cold bites your legs, the current shoves, and you shove back. You make it across soaked and shaking—but alive—and you salvage enough from the crossing to count it as a gain rather than a loss.

fail.text: The river takes more than it gives. You fight it until your lungs burn and your muscles turn to rope. You reach the far bank by stubbornness alone, then collapse with the kind of fatigue that makes even simple choices feel heavy.

outcomes.title: Build a Raft
outcomes.desc: Make safety out of wood, rope, and careful thinking.

success.text: You choose the right logs, bind them well, and test before you trust. The raft dips and sways, but it holds. You land on the far side with your gear intact and even manage to keep a few useful materials from the build.

fail.text: The knot slips. The raft yaws. For a moment you’re certain you’ve built your own coffin. You make it across, but you lose supplies to the river and time to sheer stress—and both costs cling to you afterward.

outcomes.title: Pay the Ferryman
outcomes.desc: Coin buys dry boots—if the boat doesn’t leak and the man doesn’t lie.

success.text: The ferryman takes your coin with the solemnity of a priest receiving tithe. The crossing is uneventful—mercifully so. You step onto the far bank dry, annoyed, and safe.

fail.text: He takes your coin and then charges you again in ‘fees’ you can’t argue while sitting in his boat. By the time you’re across, you’re poorer than you planned and missing a bit of your provisions as well—whether to theft or ‘accident,’ the river doesn’t say.

outcomes.title: Cross at Night
outcomes.desc: Avoid eyes on the bridge and gamble that darkness will be kinder than law.

success.text: You find a narrow place where the river listens more than it roars, and you move when the world is half asleep. On the far side you discover why the bridge is watched: the crossing is a seam in someone else’s quiet business. You don’t disturb it—just learn from it.

fail.text: A lantern flares. A shout rises. You’re only a silhouette for a heartbeat, but in that heartbeat someone decides you’re worth chasing. You get away, but the night has made you suspicious in the eyes of people who carry badges.

name: Swamp Detour
prompt: At Frostbarrow Pass, where winter bargains hard and mercy is expensive, the road sinks into swamp like a bad promise. Mosquitoes rise in clouds, and the ground argues with every step. Somewhere out there is firmer land—if you can find it before the mire taxes your will, your supplies, or your health.

outcomes.title: Push Through
outcomes.desc: Put your head down and endure the wet, the biting, and the slow grind.

success.text: You refuse to bargain with the swamp. You move steadily, never stopping long enough for doubt to settle in your bones. When you finally reach dry ground, you feel oddly proud—like you’ve outlasted something that wanted you to become small.

fail.text: The swamp wins in inches. Your boots soak through, your skin breaks out, your throat turns raw with bad air. By the time you reach shelter, sickness has already moved in like an unwanted tenant.

outcomes.title: Find High Ground
outcomes.desc: Read the land and take the longer path that doesn’t try to swallow you.

success.text: You spot reeds that mean shallows and trees that mean roots you can trust. The route is slower, but safer. It costs supplies and patience, yet spares you the worst of the swamp’s hunger.

fail.text: You choose what looks like solid ground—and it isn’t. You backtrack, you detour, you slog. By the time you’re out, you’ve bled supplies and picked up a cough that sounds like dampness lodged in your chest.

outcomes.title: Hire a Guide
outcomes.desc: Pay someone who grew up on this mire to lead you through its moods.

success.text: A local takes your coin and then takes you by a route you would never have dared alone—half hidden trails, half superstition, all effective. You arrive with more provisions than you expected, and a new appreciation for the kind of knowledge cities don’t teach.

fail.text: The guide leads you through—yes—but makes sure you understand it wasn’t charity. The coin is taken, and afterward comes the ‘favor,’ spoken softly like a shared secret. You make it out, but you’re no longer traveling alone; you’re traveling with a hook in your future.

outcomes.title: Cut Corners
outcomes.desc: Slip where others slog, take risks, and try to come out ahead.

success.text: You move light and fast, stepping where you shouldn’t and trusting instincts over maps. You find a stash—left by smugglers or a desperate traveler—and pocket both goods and a telling detail about who uses this swamp as cover.

fail.text: You gamble on speed and the swamp calls it arrogance. You get turned around, fight leeches and sucking mud, and claw your way out with nothing gained but fatigue that sits in your limbs like lead.

name: Broken Compass
prompt: At Frostbarrow Pass, where winter bargains hard and mercy is expensive, your compass needle spins like a frightened animal. North, south—meaningless. The sky is hazy, the paths fork too often, and the day is already leaning toward evening. Getting lost isn’t dramatic. It’s slow, quiet, and hungry.

outcomes.title: Read the Stars
outcomes.desc: Trust old knowledge and a steady sky—if the clouds allow it.

success.text: You wait for the sky to clear enough to speak, then listen to it like a seasoned sailor. The patterns line up, and the world becomes legible again. On your way you notice something you wouldn’t have seen if you’d stayed certain—an odd track, a hidden sign, a small secret the land gave up to patience.

fail.text: The haze refuses to lift, and your certainty erodes into guesswork. You wander, backtrack, and pay for every wrong turn in food and time. By the time you find a real path, your pack has become noticeably lighter.

outcomes.title: Follow the River
outcomes.desc: Water leads somewhere—eventually. The question is whether you can afford ‘eventually.’

success.text: You pick a direction and commit, letting the river’s logic replace your compass. It takes longer than you’d like, and it costs you supplies, but it also gives you something useful: momentum. Lost people die when they hesitate.

fail.text: The river bends, doubles back, disappears into reeds, then returns as if mocking you. You keep moving anyway until your body makes its opinion known. You find your way, but you do it tired and frayed, the kind of state that invites later mistakes.

outcomes.title: Ask the Locals
outcomes.desc: Put pride away and seek directions from people who belong to this land.

success.text: You approach with respect instead of demands, and the locals respond like you’ve treated them as people rather than scenery. They point you true, warn you about a bad stretch ahead, and in doing so, tie a small thread of goodwill to your name.

fail.text: Your request comes out wrong—too entitled, too suspicious, too desperate. The locals stiffen, answer curtly, and you leave with directions that feel like a dismissal. You’re not harmed, but you are diminished in their eyes, and that feeling sticks.

outcomes.title: Steal a Map
outcomes.desc: If you can’t find the way, take it from someone who already has.

success.text: A satchel left unattended is an invitation, and you accept it with quiet hands. The map inside is better than you hoped—marked routes, private shortcuts, and a note about a patrol schedule that feels very useful indeed.

fail.text: A shout catches you mid-step. Someone grabs at your sleeve, and the whole village seems to sprout eyes. You run, you escape, but you do it with a new problem: being remembered as the sort of person who takes.

name: The Hungry Year
prompt: In Wrenfield, where plague taught people to count breaths and measure trust, the roads are thin with travelers and thick with staring eyes. Markets sell emptier sacks for higher prices. Even friendly faces measure your pack as if doing math. Hunger doesn’t make monsters—it just makes choices honest.

outcomes.title: Ration Strictly
outcomes.desc: Count every bite. Treat appetite like an enemy that must be managed.

success.text: You make rules and follow them even when your stomach argues. The pack shrinks, but it doesn’t vanish. It’s a small victory—quiet, grinding, real—earned by refusing to panic.

fail.text: Discipline breaks in tiny moments: an extra mouthful here, a ‘just this once’ there. Then one day you look in the pack and see too much cloth and not enough food. Hunger moves in hard and fast, turning your thoughts sharp at the edges.

outcomes.title: Buy Grain
outcomes.desc: Pay now, eat later—if the seller isn’t lying and the road doesn’t steal it.

success.text: You swallow the unfair price and buy enough grain to make the next weeks feel survivable. The sack is heavy, comforting in its own blunt way. People stare, but you keep moving—food is safest when it’s already behind you.

fail.text: You pay the price and still don’t get what you wanted—shorted measures, damp grain, promises that rot by morning. It helps, but not enough, and the sting of being cheated sits beside the fear of running out.

outcomes.title: Take What You Need
outcomes.desc: When the world refuses you bread, you refuse the world’s rules.

success.text: You make it quick—no cruelty, no speeches, just a hard decision carried out with hard hands. You get enough to keep moving, but you also earn what all theft earns in lean times: eyes that remember, and mouths that talk.

fail.text: Someone resists, someone screams, and suddenly it’s not a desperate act—it’s a public crime. The chase is immediate. Even if you escape, the hungry year has one more thing it’s good at: turning people into informants.

outcomes.title: Work for Your Meal
outcomes.desc: Trade sweat for bread and accept that survival can be humiliating.

success.text: You haul sacks, mend fences, dig ditches—whatever the day demands. It’s not glorious, but it’s honest work in a dishonest season. You earn a meal, a little coin, and the kind of fatigue that at least comes with proof it mattered.

fail.text: You push too hard and your body pushes back. A wrong lift, a long day, a night without enough rest—then the exhaustion settles in deep. You still get fed, but you pay for it with strength you can’t easily buy back.

name: The Ruined Watchtower
prompt: Along the Sable Coast, where the sea keeps what it takes and gives back strangers, the watchtower’s bones still stand, though the roof is long gone and rain has eaten the mortar into soft grit. Birds nest where sentries once paced. Inside, the air smells of wet stone and old ash. Something catches the light in the rubble—metal, glass, or the pale gleam of coin. A place like this doesn’t keep its treasures without keeping a price beside them.

outcomes.title: Search Carefully
outcomes.desc: Go slow, listen for the tower’s small warnings, and let patience earn the find.

success.text: You test each beam before you trust it, shift stones with a stick instead of your hands, and pause when the tower creaks as if remembering how to fall. Under a loose flagstone you find a small cache: a few coins wrapped in oilcloth and a note—half-rotted, but legible enough to hint at who once used this place and why. You leave with money in your pouch and a detail that feels like it could open a door later.

fail.text: You pick your way through damp rubble and stale droppings, breathing more dust than you should. The find is there—some coin, a trinket—but so is the consequence. By the time you step back into daylight, your throat burns and your chest feels tight, like the tower decided to keep part of you as payment.

outcomes.title: Force the Door
outcomes.desc: Make entry a simple problem with a simple solution: strength.

success.text: You shoulder the warped door until the rusted hinge gives with a scream of metal. Inside, you tear through debris like you’re chasing an enemy. Whatever glinted wasn’t imagination—coin, scattered and half-buried, perhaps dropped in panic years ago. You scoop it up and leave before the tower can argue.

fail.text: The door gives—but not cleanly. A splintered plank snaps back, or a hidden nail catches flesh, or the frame collapses just enough to bite. You get inside, you get something, but you come out bleeding and annoyed at how quickly a ‘simple’ approach turns costly.

outcomes.title: Look for Traps
outcomes.desc: Assume someone clever expected someone greedy, and try to be neither.

success.text: You find the signs—scratched stone where a wire once ran, a footprint pattern too consistent to be chance, a broken jar of old pitch used to mark paths in the dark. The ‘treasure’ was bait, but the structure of the bait is the real reward. You leave without taking much, but with the knowledge of who set such snares and the sort of work they were doing.

fail.text: You’re careful—just not careful enough. Something clatters, something shifts, and a sound carries farther than it should in open country. Later, on the road, you notice riders watching you a little too long, as if someone has already decided you’re the kind of person who rummages in places that aren’t theirs.

outcomes.title: Leave It Be
outcomes.desc: Refuse the tower’s invitation and walk away with your luck intact.

success.text: You turn away, not because you’re uninterested, but because you can smell the trouble on the air. Down the road you help a traveler who’s stuck in the mud, or you share a word with a local who appreciates restraint. It’s the kind of small, decent choice people remember when they decide who to trust.

fail.text: You walk away… but you keep looking back. The tower sits in your mind like an itch, and the indecision nags at you. Nothing bad happens—nothing good either. Just the quiet irritation of an unanswered question.

name: Forbidden Folio
prompt: In Gloambridge, where every tavern has a scholar and a spy, the folio is wrapped in oilcloth like contraband. The ink is old, the margins dense with a second hand arguing the first. Nothing glows. Nothing whispers. And yet you can feel the danger in the way the author assumes they will not be forgiven. Here is knowledge that makes enemies merely by existing.

outcomes.title: Study in Secret
outcomes.desc: Read enough to benefit—before it can bite.

success.text: You copy the key passage into memory and stop before obsession can take hold. The work is brilliant in the way a knife is brilliant: honest about what it does.

fail.text: You read too long, too greedily. Sleep comes thin. Your thoughts take a strange angle. The folio doesn’t need sorcery to harm you—only persistence.

outcomes.title: Fence It Quietly
outcomes.desc: Turn dangerous knowledge into safer coin.

success.text: A collector receives it with shaking hands and too many questions you do not answer. You leave with heavy purse and heavier suspicions about who will read it next.

fail.text: The handoff draws notice. Someone follows you long enough to learn your gait, your habits, the places you think are private.

outcomes.title: Hide It for a Time
outcomes.desc: Keep it close, but not *too* close.

success.text: You stash it where damp and eyes are unlikely to find it. You tell yourself it’s prudence. You do not tell yourself how quickly you’ll want it back.

fail.text: The hiding place is not as clever as you thought. Later, you catch someone looking at you like they know a secret you don’t.

outcomes.title: Offer It to a Shrine
outcomes.desc: Let piety take custody of what you shouldn’t own.

success.text: You place it in careful hands and accept the quiet gratitude of those who keep dangerous things locked away.

fail.text: They accept your gift with polite distance, as if you’ve brought rot into a clean place. Word leaks anyway—never with full detail, always with enough to sting.

name: Village Relic
prompt: At Verdemont Abbey, where vines climb stone and confession is a kind of currency, a village meets you at the edge of the road as if they’ve been rehearsing the plea. Their relic is gone—wood and metal, worn smooth by hands that needed something to hold onto. ‘It’s not valuable,’ they insist, which is exactly why the loss hurts. A thief took it anyway, and now the villagers look at the empty shrine like it’s a wound that won’t stop bleeding.

outcomes.title: Recover It
outcomes.desc: Go after the thief and bring the relic back the hard way: by force and endurance.

success.text: You track the culprit by the simple signs desperate people miss—mud on a boot, a snapped twig, a hurried path that tries to pretend it’s not hurried. When you catch them, they don’t fold gracefully. It takes effort, bruises, and a little fear. But you return with the relic intact, and the village’s relief turns into a kind of reverence you didn’t ask for.

fail.text: You find the thief, or what the thief left behind, and the encounter turns messy. A blow lands wrong. A scuffle ends with you bleeding. You return empty-handed or too late, and the village’s disappointment settles on you like damp cloth.

outcomes.title: Research Its History
outcomes.desc: Learn who took it—and why—by treating the relic as a story, not a trinket.

success.text: You ask about old feuds, note who looks away when certain names are spoken, and read the village’s records with the patience of someone who expects lies. The relic isn’t ‘just’ a relic—its history points to a local power playing games. When you share what you’ve learned, the villagers treat you differently: not as muscle, but as someone whose insight can protect them.

fail.text: You dig too deep in a place that survives by keeping things simple. People bristle at your questions; old resentments flare; your search becomes a day-long slog through half-truths. You leave tired, with little to show for it but the sense you’ve stirred a pot that will keep boiling after you’re gone.

outcomes.title: Swap It for a Fake
outcomes.desc: Give them comfort, keep the value—make the story true enough to live with.

success.text: You ‘recover’ something that looks right in the lamplight and feels right to hopeful hands. The village embraces it like a miracle, and you walk away with the original tucked safely away and profit weighing your purse. The lie is clean—until it isn’t.

fail.text: Someone notices. A grandmother who’s touched the relic a thousand times, a child who remembers the nick on the edge, a priest who knows the weight in their palm. The fake becomes an insult, and your cleverness turns into shame that travels faster than you do.

outcomes.title: Offer a Blessing
outcomes.desc: You can’t fight every battle, but you can leave people steadier than you found them.

success.text: You speak to them like their grief deserves dignity, not dismissal. You help repair the shrine, light a candle, say the right small words—more comfort than ceremony. It doesn’t replace the relic, but it gives the village something else: resolve. And in return, they offer you what they can—support, shelter, a good word in nearby places.

fail.text: Your attempt lands wrong—too formal, too hollow, too much like a traveler pretending to care. They nod politely and you leave, but the village keeps its hurt. Some problems can’t be smoothed over with a speech.

name: Old Stone Circle
prompt: In Gloambridge, where every tavern has a scholar and a spy, ancient stones stand in a ring like teeth around a silent mouth. Lichen maps their surfaces in pale greens, and shallow carvings run beneath the growth—lines that look like writing until you stare too long. The air inside the circle feels… attentive. Not magical, exactly. Just older than comfort. People have left offerings at the bases of a few stones: coins, ribbons, a broken knife laid down with surprising care.

outcomes.title: Camp Within the Ring
outcomes.desc: Rest where few dare rest, and see what kind of sleep the old stones allow.

success.text: You set your bedroll inside the circle and keep the fire low. The night is quiet in a way that feels deliberate. Your dreams come sharp and coherent—half memory, half warning—and when you wake, the fatigue that’s been clinging to you has loosened. In the ash near your fire you find something you didn’t place there: a small sign, a pattern, a detail that feels like a private message from the world’s older layers.

fail.text: Sleep doesn’t come gently. The wind moves even when the trees don’t. Shadows lean the wrong way. By morning you feel like you’ve been watched all night by something that doesn’t blink. You leave the circle with the cold certainty that you brought something out with you—something that will not be satisfied by distance alone.

outcomes.title: Take a Rubbing
outcomes.desc: Record the symbols like a scholar, not a pilgrim—proof matters later.

success.text: You press charcoal to paper and let the carvings reveal themselves in negative space. The pattern isn’t random—it repeats, shifts, hides a structure. It’s the kind of knowledge that doesn’t make you powerful by itself, but does make you dangerous when paired with the right moment.

fail.text: The damp air and the circle’s chill sink into you while you work. Your fingers go numb, your breath turns shallow, and you find yourself coughing as if you’ve inhaled the age of the stones. You take what notes you can, but you leave with a sickness that feels like the circle didn’t appreciate being ‘studied.’

outcomes.title: Carve Your Mark
outcomes.desc: Leave proof you were here—bold enough that the world can’t pretend you were small.

success.text: You choose a stone and cut your sign into it with deliberate strokes. It’s not vandalism in your mind—it’s a claim: I stood here, I endured the feeling, I left something of myself behind. Later, when people speak of the ring, your mark becomes part of the tale.

fail.text: The stone resists the blade, and your courage turns into awkward persistence. A slip, a crack, a sound like laughter carried on wind. You finish anyway, but the act feels wrong in your gut. You leave with the sensation of being tagged—noticed—like an animal that wandered too close to a snare.

outcomes.title: Loot the Offerings
outcomes.desc: If coins sit unattended, they are simply waiting for a more practical owner.

success.text: You pocket the offerings quickly—coins, a bit of dried food, a flask half-full. It feels easy, almost ridiculous that people would leave wealth to stones. And then the easy part ends: you notice tracks nearby, someone else’s attention on the ring… or perhaps on you. You’ve gained materially, but you’ve also stepped into a story where you’re the villain.

fail.text: Your hand closes on cold coin and the air inside the circle turns sharper, like the world inhaled. Whether it’s superstition or something real doesn’t matter—your nerves decide it’s real. Worse, someone sees you leaving with bulging pockets. You walk away richer, yes, but also dirtier in ways coin can’t wash.

name: Tavern Brawl
prompt: In the Greenfold, where small villages hide big hungers, the tavern is loud in the way that makes mistakes feel like inevitability. Someone says something cheap. Someone else hears it like a knife. A chair scrapes back, a mug shatters, and suddenly the room is a storm of fists and splinters. In a brawl, nobody is innocent—only quicker or slower to choose a side.

outcomes.title: Drop the Loudest One
outcomes.desc: End it fast: remove the spark before it becomes a fire.

success.text: You pick the one driving the chaos—the mouth that keeps provoking, the hands that keep swinging—and you put them down with a single decisive blow. The room hesitates. That hesitation is all it takes. The brawl breaks into smaller scuffles, then embarrassment. Someone presses a coin into your palm for ‘restoring order,’ and you leave with a rough kind of respect.

fail.text: You commit to ending it quickly and instead become the center of it. Someone cheap-shots you from the side, a bottle breaks, and pain floods bright and immediate. You still fight your way clear, but you do it bleeding, and the tavern’s story about you will begin with the wound.

outcomes.title: Win With Positioning
outcomes.desc: Let the room do the work—tables, doorways, and timing are weapons too.

success.text: You keep your back to a wall, steer attackers into each other, and use the furniture like a chessboard. People fall where you intend them to. When the shouting dies down, you’re still standing, breathing hard, looking like someone who knows how to survive a messy room.

fail.text: You try to be clever, but chaos doesn’t always respect clever. A misstep, a stumble, a moment too long calculating, and suddenly you’re burning through energy just to stay upright. You live through it, but the exertion follows you out into the night like a weight on your shoulders.

outcomes.title: Turn It Into a Shakedown
outcomes.desc: If everyone’s frightened already, profit is just a matter of aim.

success.text: You grab someone by the collar, bark a threat that sounds like authority, and ‘confiscate’ their purse in the name of ‘keeping them safe.’ Others see it and decide not to argue. In the scramble you learn a useful thing too—who in this tavern is connected, who is afraid, and who will pay to avoid attention.

fail.text: You try to squeeze coin from panic and discover someone in the room has sharper instincts than you. A hand clamps your wrist, a voice calls you out, and suddenly the brawl has a new target: the ‘thief’ in plain sight. You escape, but the wrong eyes remember your face.

outcomes.title: Calm the Room
outcomes.desc: Stop the riot with a voice steadier than the fear driving it.

success.text: You step between bodies and speak like someone who belongs there. Not louder—clearer. You name consequences, offer a way to save face, and give the anger somewhere to land that isn’t someone’s teeth. The room cools by degrees. A few people glance at you afterward as if you’ve earned a small claim on their respect.

fail.text: Your words get swallowed by the noise. Worse, someone interprets your attempt as taking a side. A mug flies, a shout rises, and you become part of the story in the least flattering way: the fool who thought talking could stop fists.

name: Arrow From the Treeline
prompt: In Stonewold, where iron sings and tempers run as hot as the forges, an arrow thuds into the dirt beside your boot—close enough to be deliberate. The treeline is still. No bandit cry, no demands, no laughter. Just the message: someone has range, patience, and the choice of whether the next shot lands in soil or flesh.

outcomes.title: Charge the Line
outcomes.desc: If you let them keep distance, you die by distance.

success.text: You close fast, violent and certain. Whoever watched you decides you’re not an easy kill today.

fail.text: You sprint into angles you cannot see. The second arrow finds you where confidence becomes exposure.

outcomes.title: Read the Terrain
outcomes.desc: Find the nest by thinking like a hunter.

success.text: Broken twigs, a scraped bark, the faintest footprint. You don’t catch them, but you learn enough to avoid the kill zone—and to remember the pattern.

fail.text: You circle, hesitate, double back. The day stretches into nerves and sweat until you’re too tired to keep being clever.

outcomes.title: Vanish Into Cover
outcomes.desc: Give them nothing to shoot at.

success.text: You become a rumor in your own wake—footprints broken, silhouette swallowed. If they pursue, they do it blind.

fail.text: A snapped branch, a flash of movement, a third heartbeat you didn’t account for. You escape—but now you’re the one being tracked.

outcomes.title: Call for Parley
outcomes.desc: Turn a threat into information, if they’ll speak.

success.text: You speak as if you have options. After a long pause, a voice answers—thin, controlled, afraid of being named. You don’t get a face, but you get intent.

fail.text: Your words drift into silence. The reply is another arrow—closer.

name: Hunt Gone Wrong
prompt: In Stonewold, where iron sings and tempers run as hot as the forges, the hunt was meant to be routine: track, stalk, kill, eat. Instead, the woods shift and the air turns sharp. Something larger than you expected moves where it shouldn’t. Your quarry stops being food and becomes a problem with teeth, weight, and the will to make you bleed.

outcomes.title: Bring It Down
outcomes.desc: End the threat decisively and claim the meat like you meant to from the start.

success.text: You commit—no hesitation, no bargaining with fear. The creature charges and you meet it, turning the encounter into a brutal argument your body is willing to win. When it finally falls, the forest goes quiet again. You butcher quickly, take what you can carry, and walk away with both food and the grim pride of surviving what tried to end you.

fail.text: You strike, you wrestle, you scramble—and the beast makes contact in the way beasts do: sudden, total, indifferent. Pain flares as it catches you, and you escape only by giving ground and blood. The hunt ends with you limping and angry, carrying the memory of teeth more than meat.

outcomes.title: Outthink the Beast
outcomes.desc: Make the terrain your ally: angles, choke points, and timing instead of brute force.

success.text: You pull it toward mud that slows it, toward branches that snag, toward a slope that steals its momentum. When it commits, you punish the commitment. The kill is messy but earned, and you take enough meat to make the danger feel worth it—barely.

fail.text: Your plan is good, but the wilderness doesn’t care about good plans. The beast moves in a way you didn’t predict, and you spend the fight running, climbing, and praying your feet stay under you. You get away with some meat—scraps, really—but you pay for it with fatigue that bites as sharply as fear.

outcomes.title: Lay a Dirty Trap
outcomes.desc: Win in a way you won’t boast about: cruel, clever, and effective.

success.text: You bait it with blood, set it where the ground gives, and use the kind of trick hunters don’t admit to in company. The beast dies ugly and fast. While you work, you notice something off—a collar remnant, a strange cut on the hide, a sign it wasn’t as wild as it looked. That detail is worth keeping, along with the meat.

fail.text: The trap works—on you. You cut corners, handle foul bait, and end up with a sickness that settles in after the adrenaline fades. The beast escapes, and you’re left with the worst outcome: no meal, and a body that feels compromised.

outcomes.title: Back Away Slowly
outcomes.desc: Choose survival over pride. Live to hunt something less interested in killing you.

success.text: You control your breathing, keep your posture calm, and retreat without turning it into a chase. The forest lets you go. If fatigue has been riding you, the choice feels like shedding a burden—one fewer disaster you had to wrestle into submission.

fail.text: You try to disengage and the woods punish hesitation. You lose time, lose ground, and end up burning through supplies to make up for the detour and the fear. The creature doesn’t kill you—just costs you.

name: Guard Captain’s Suspicion
prompt: Outside Briarwatch, where the frontier keeps its teeth, a guard captain steps into your path with the easy confidence of someone backed by steel and paperwork. Their hand rests near the hilt, not gripping—just reminding. “State your business.” Behind them, two guards watch your hands more than your face. This isn’t a fight yet. It’s a decision about what kind of story you’re going to be today.

outcomes.title: Stand Tall
outcomes.desc: Make your presence an argument: posture, certainty, and the implication you belong.

success.text: You meet the captain’s eyes without flinching and speak like someone accustomed to being answered. You don’t over-explain; you don’t apologize. The captain reads your confidence, weighs the inconvenience of delaying you, and decides today isn’t worth the trouble. As they step aside, you feel the law’s grip loosen—if only a little.

fail.text: You try to project authority and it comes out as arrogance. The captain’s mouth tightens. The guards shift their stance. Your words become evidence of attitude rather than legitimacy, and you’re waved through with the kind of disdain that sticks to your name afterward.

outcomes.title: Explain Precisely
outcomes.desc: Offer details that withstand inspection—dates, names, and a story that doesn’t wobble.

success.text: You answer the captain’s questions before they fully ask them. The rhythm of your explanation sounds practiced, believable. They still don’t like you—but they can’t find the seam to tug. As you leave, you catch a useful fragment: the name of a superior, a shift schedule, a detail about what they’re really watching for.

fail.text: You provide details, and the details become a net. One inconsistency, one stutter, one forgotten name—suddenly every question multiplies. You get through, but it takes time and energy you didn’t plan to spend, and you walk away wrung out by scrutiny.

outcomes.title: Slip Past the Net
outcomes.desc: Be gone before questions become chains—quiet feet, hidden angles, no second chances.

success.text: You vanish into the crowd’s blind spots, move when they blink, and pass the checkpoint as if you were never meant to stop there. Behind you, the captain’s voice rises in irritation, but it’s too late—you’re already on the far side, carrying a small advantage: the knowledge that the law can be slipped if you respect its patterns.

fail.text: You make your move and someone notices the shape of it. A shout goes up. Boots hit cobblestone. Now you’re not a traveler—you’re a suspect with urgency attached. Even if you escape, you escape into a harsher category of trouble.

outcomes.title: Break and Run
outcomes.desc: If they won’t listen, outrun them—make distance the only argument.

success.text: You explode into motion, shoulder through a gap, and turn the checkpoint into a chase. For a few frantic moments, it’s you versus the city. You clear a fence, slam through an alley, and leave the guards cursing behind you. People saw it—some with fear, some with admiration. Either way, your name grows sharper at the edges.

fail.text: You run, and the captain runs too—along with men trained to catch runners. A baton catches ribs, a fall scrapes skin, a blade kisses you where it shouldn’t. You get away or get dragged back, but either way the attempt leaves its mark in blood and pain.

name: Stolen Correspondence
prompt: In Marrowgate, where tolls are tradition and corruption is a local craft, a bundle of letters falls into your hands—sealed, scented, and written with the reckless confidence of people who assume servants are deaf and walls are loyal. Names appear often enough to matter. So do promises. You could profit, you could threaten, you could decode what they’re really saying… or you could burn the weapon before you learn to love holding it.

outcomes.title: Sell Them Quietly
outcomes.desc: Let someone else swing the blade. You keep the coin.

success.text: A discreet buyer pays fast and asks no questions—because they already know the answers.

fail.text: You choose the wrong intermediary. Your ‘discretion’ becomes evidence.

outcomes.title: Use Them for Leverage
outcomes.desc: A quiet threat can move a loud world.

success.text: You never raise your voice. You don’t have to. The right sentence, placed carefully, buys you favors that feel like fear wearing perfume.

fail.text: Your hint lands wrong. Someone decides you’re either bluffing or dangerous—either way, they want you watched.

outcomes.title: Decode the Pattern
outcomes.desc: Read between lines, find the real message.

success.text: Dates, routes, payments—this is not romance. It’s logistics.

fail.text: You spend the day chasing implications until your eyes ache.

outcomes.title: Burn Them
outcomes.desc: Refuse the addiction of leverage.

success.text: The ash feels strangely light in your palm.

fail.text: Someone notices the smoke and asks what you’re hiding.

name: Rumor Mill
prompt: In the city, truth is only one ingredient. The rest is tone, timing, and who repeats the story first. You catch your name in a conversation that stops when you turn your head. Somewhere nearby, a rumor is being shaped like clay—into a crown, a noose, or a coin purse. You can steer the whispers, hunt their source, or pretend you’re above the game. The city rarely rewards pride for long.

outcomes.title: Plant a Favorable Tale
outcomes.desc: Feed the gossip something sweet, so your name tastes better than your rivals'.

success.text: You choose the right mouths—barmaids, scribes, guards with loose lips—and you give them a story that sounds like they discovered it themselves. Within days, your name is spoken with a slightly different tilt: admiration, curiosity, a hint of inevitability. It isn’t love, but it’s momentum, and momentum is power.

fail.text: You push too hard, or the tale is too polished, too convenient. People smell the manipulation and resent being handled. Your attempted shine turns into something oily—‘trying too much,’ ‘not as impressive as they claim’—and the whispering grows teeth.

outcomes.title: Spook Your Rivals
outcomes.desc: Let them feel watched—because being watched makes people make mistakes.

success.text: A message left half-visible. A conversation interrupted at the perfect moment. A familiar face seen where it shouldn’t be. You don’t threaten directly—you simply imply consequences. Your rivals tighten, stumble, and suddenly spend their energy protecting themselves instead of harming you. In the tension, you learn something useful about where they keep their fears.

fail.text: Your ‘spooking’ looks a lot like harassment to the wrong witness. A guard takes an interest. A clerk writes your name down. Your rivals don’t feel threatened—they feel vindicated, and they make sure the city’s attention swivels toward you.

outcomes.title: Verify What’s True
outcomes.desc: Separate malice from fact—because only one of them can be cleanly dealt with.

success.text: You follow the rumor the way you’d follow a trail: backward, step by step, through the hands that passed it along. You find the break where truth becomes performance. Knowing that difference lets you respond precisely—and you correct the record in small, undeniable ways. If your reputation was bruised, it begins to mend.

fail.text: You chase the rumor through alleys of half-truth and spite. Every source points to another source, every certainty dissolves into ‘I heard.’ By the time you stop, you’ve spent a day wrestling smoke—and the effort leaves you drained and no closer to safety.

outcomes.title: Ignore It Entirely
outcomes.desc: Refuse to feed the fire. Sometimes starved rumors die. Sometimes they learn to hunt.

success.text: You keep your routines, keep your face calm, and never give the whisperers the satisfaction of a reaction. Without fuel, the story struggles to stay interesting. For a time, it loses traction—people move on to easier targets.

fail.text: Your silence is interpreted the way crowds love to interpret silence: as an admission. The rumor hardens while you stand still, and by the time you notice the damage, your name has already been bent into something less flattering.

name: Hidden Safehouse
prompt: In Kestrelbank, where bridges and ledgers decide who eats, a hooded figure offers you a safehouse: a quiet room above a shop, a cellar with a second door, a place where questions don’t arrive with daylight. The offer smells of generosity—and hooks. Safehouses are never free. They are paid in coin, in favors, or in the slow realization that someone now knows where you sleep.

outcomes.title: Accept Shelter
outcomes.desc: Rest now. Untangle the cost later.

success.text: You sleep without listening for boots. For a few days, the city feels less sharp.

fail.text: The door locks a little too easily behind you. The kindness comes with terms you didn’t agree to—at least, not out loud.

outcomes.title: Inspect for Traps
outcomes.desc: Assume every gift is bait.

success.text: You find the pressure points: who owns the building, who has keys, who watches the alley.

fail.text: You hesitate too long and lose the chance to vanish cleanly.

outcomes.title: Use It as a Decoy
outcomes.desc: If someone set bait, let them choke on it.

success.text: You turn their generosity into your advantage and leave with profit and an intact exit.

fail.text: Your play is noticed. The city gets smaller around you.

outcomes.title: Refuse and Relocate
outcomes.desc: Keep independence, pay in fatigue.

success.text: You find another roof through your own network and keep your name clean.

fail.text: You spend the night walking and listening and never truly resting.

name: Smuggler’s Choice
prompt: In Kestrelbank, where bridges and ledgers decide who eats, a smuggler offers you work under moonlight. They don’t say ‘crime.’ They say ‘opportunity.’ A crate can be ‘goods.’ A hooded figure can be ‘cargo.’ The same boat carries both, and the same silence buys both. If you accept, you profit. If you refuse, you stay clean. If you betray them, you invite consequences that never knock politely.

outcomes.title: Move Goods
outcomes.desc: Fast coin for quiet labor.

success.text: You deliver the crate without asking what it is. You’re paid like someone who understands how to keep breathing.

fail.text: A lantern turns. A shout follows. You run with the sound of your own name in someone else’s mouth.

outcomes.title: Move a Person
outcomes.desc: A life delivered buys heavier favors than coin.

success.text: You get them through without panic. They never forget the hand that didn’t shake.

fail.text: They arrive—but frightened, injured, or late. The smuggler smiles like you now owe interest.

outcomes.title: Negotiate a Better Cut
outcomes.desc: Respect is currency. Take your share in it.

success.text: You speak as if you can walk away. They believe you—and pay to keep you.

fail.text: They decide you’re arrogant, not valuable. The insult sticks longer than the coin would have.

outcomes.title: Turn Them In
outcomes.desc: Make the law do your violence for you.

success.text: You give the guards the right detail at the right moment. Someone else is in chains by dawn.

fail.text: The smugglers smell betrayal before the guards arrive. The docks become less safe for a while.

name: Disputed Inheritance
prompt: At Ashqar’s oasis court, where shade and law trade places by noon, two claimants corner you with smiles that don’t reach their eyes. One has paper. One has friends with swords. Both want your public support, because your support is a story they can tell the room. You can weigh the law, weigh the power, build a compromise, or profit from the uncertainty—knowing that people remember who they begged.

outcomes.title: Back the Lawful Claim
outcomes.desc: Let documents outweigh threats—out loud.

success.text: You make the case cleanly. The room leans toward order.

fail.text: Your argument becomes ‘interference.’ The powerful laugh, and the lawful glare.

outcomes.title: Back the Powerful Claim
outcomes.desc: Bet on the winner the hall has already chosen.

success.text: You align with force and gain access that feels like safety.

fail.text: The weaker claimant leaves in humiliation—and spends the next weeks trying to make you feel some of it.

outcomes.title: Forge a Compromise
outcomes.desc: Split the prize. Absorb the blame.

success.text: You hammer out a peace that satisfies no one and prevents bloodshed anyway.

fail.text: You spend hours negotiating and end with nothing but fatigue and resentment.

outcomes.title: Profit in the Shadows
outcomes.desc: Sell your support twice and call it ‘strategy.’

success.text: You take payment from both sides and keep your smile steady.

fail.text: Someone compares notes. Suddenly you’re not clever—you’re criminal.

name: Trial of a Friend
prompt: At Ashqar’s oasis court, where shade and law trade places by noon, the courtroom smells of ink, sweat, and old authority. Your friend stands where the accused stand: shoulders squared, eyes tired, trying not to look at you too much. Their charge is the kind that stains by proximity. Helping them is not merely kindness—it is alignment. The judge watches. The crowd watches. And somewhere in the back, someone who benefits from your friend’s fall watches most closely of all.

outcomes.title: Speak for Them
outcomes.desc: Put your name behind theirs and make the room feel your conviction.

success.text: You speak clearly, not begging but insisting—on context, on character, on the gap between accusation and proof. You make the court imagine itself as fair again. It doesn’t save your friend by miracle; it saves them by shifting the room’s mood from hunger to hesitation. When it’s over, your friend lives to owe you, and your courage becomes something others must account for.

fail.text: Your defense becomes the spectacle the court wanted—just not in the way you intended. A misstep is seized, a phrase is twisted, and suddenly you are not a defender of fairness but an accomplice in the crowd’s imagination. The verdict stains you along with your friend.

outcomes.title: Find Exonerating Detail
outcomes.desc: Dig for the one fact that flips the story—dates, witnesses, contradictions.

success.text: You scour the record, talk to the right clerk, follow a detail that doesn’t fit. Somewhere in the paperwork is a seam—an impossible timeline, a forged mark, a witness who wasn’t where they claimed. You bring it forward at the right moment and watch the prosecution falter. Your friend’s case steadies, and you walk away with both leverage and quiet gratitude.
