fail.text: Mercy sounds like weakness to a room full of fresh wounds. Your words are swallowed, then spat back as mockery. You keep talking anyway until your throat burns and your hope feels stupid.

name: Tracks in the Scree
prompt: The trail climbs into the Ironspine where the wind scours footprints from the earth like chalk from slate. Cairns watch you with blank patience. Somewhere ahead, a campfire smokes, and the broken vow has hands and a mouth and a heartbeat.

outcomes.title: Climb Fast, Strike First
outcomes.desc: Close the distance before they can choose the ground.

success.text: You hit their edge like a falling stone. The fight is brief, ugly, and decisive—the kind people later describe with careful omissions. When it’s done, you have what you came for: proof, and a silence that feels earned.

fail.text: You rush the climb and find a blade waiting. Pain blooms bright and immediate. You escape with your life and little else—except the certainty that your enemy now knows your face.

outcomes.title: Shadow Their Camp
outcomes.desc: Watch first. Let patience do the cutting.

success.text: You learn their habits: who stands watch, who drinks, who prays. In the dark you steal a scrap of evidence—names, routes, a ring fragment—enough to make later words land like blows.

fail.text: A loose stone betrays you. A shout goes up. You vanish into the scree with your lungs on fire, alive—but shaken, and very aware that the mountain doesn’t care which side is ‘right.’

outcomes.title: Set a Trap in the Pass
outcomes.desc: Use the land. Force them to meet you where you choose.

success.text: A rope, a false trail, a narrow turn—simple things made lethal by the right placement. When the moment comes, the mountain itself seems to side with you. The survivors flee without looking back.

fail.text: Your trap springs at the wrong time. The scramble is chaos, and you take a hard hit on stone. They get away with laughter echoing off the cliffs—a sound you’ll remember when you try to sleep.

outcomes.title: Offer Terms Before Steel
outcomes.desc: Step out openly and propose a settlement that saves face.

success.text: You speak like someone who understands what feuds cost. A pause—then a nod. They don’t confess, not in so many words, but they agree to meet on neutral ground. Sometimes that is the only victory available.

fail.text: They answer your words with spit and steel. You retreat under jeers, having offered mercy to people who only hear weakness. Your pride takes the first wound, but not the last.

name: The Bloodprice Table
prompt: In a hall built for hard winters, elders lay out cups, ledgers, and the quiet mathematics of grief. Every word is weighed. Every pause is counted. A bloodprice can end a feud—or begin a different kind of war, fought with hunger and humiliation instead of blades.

outcomes.title: Offer a Fair Bloodprice
outcomes.desc: Pay what is due—or help ensure it is paid—so the dead stay dead.

success.text: You steer the number toward something both sides can swallow. Coin changes hands with clenched teeth. It doesn’t feel like justice, but it feels like an ending—and endings are rare gifts.

fail.text: You offer what you can, and it isn’t enough. The room smells weakness and begins to negotiate around you like you’re a chair. By the time it’s done, you’ve paid more than you can afford and earned less gratitude than you hoped.

outcomes.title: Produce Witness Tokens
outcomes.desc: Bring marks, fragments, and testimony—anything that pins blame to a single throat.

success.text: Your evidence is small but sharp. A detail no liar would risk. A ring fragment that fits too perfectly. Murmurs shift into certainty, and a few faces pale as the room decides who will carry the shame.

fail.text: Your proof unravels under hostile questions. Someone smiles as if they’ve been waiting to watch you stumble. The room’s attention turns from the broken vow to your competence—and you feel yourself losing ground.

outcomes.title: Swear Yourself as Surety
outcomes.desc: Bind your own name to the settlement. If it breaks, it breaks on you.

success.text: You speak a vow that makes the hall go quiet. It’s foolish, maybe. It’s brave, certainly. People respect someone willing to pay in future pain for present peace.

fail.text: You offer surety and are met with suspicion—why would you bind yourself unless you have something to hide? They accept the vow anyway, but now it sits on your shoulders like a yoke.

outcomes.title: Intimidate for Peace
outcomes.desc: Make the cost of continuing feel immediate and personal.

success.text: You lean in with the kind of presence that makes people remember their children at home. The hall settles—not out of agreement, but out of fear of what you might do if they refuse.

fail.text: Your threat lands wrong. The hall doesn’t fear you; it resents you. Someone laughs, someone stands, and you realize you’ve made yourself the problem the room now wants to solve.

name: Burned Testimony
prompt: A vow lives in memory, but it dies in records. In Briarwatch, ink is the difference between rumor and judgment. If you want the broken oath to stay buried, you’ll need to deal with the people who write the world down.

outcomes.title: Alter the Record
outcomes.desc: Change a name, shift a date, smooth the edges until the story fits.

success.text: Your hand is steady. Your lies are plausible. When the ink dries, the broken vow is a crooked thing hidden inside a straight line. Anyone looking later will find nothing but paperwork.

fail.text: You miss a detail only a tired clerk would notice. A correction mark appears where it shouldn’t. The record doesn’t scream ‘forgery,’ but it whispers it to the wrong kind of mind.

outcomes.title: Silence a Witness
outcomes.desc: Make sure the one person who remembers the truth can’t speak it later.

success.text: It’s quick. It’s ugly. It works. The city keeps breathing, and no one knows which part of you is more shaken—the hands that did it, or the mind that decided it was necessary.

fail.text: The struggle spills into light. Someone screams. Boots thunder. You get away, but not cleanly. Now you’re not burying an oath—you’re running from the consequences of how you tried.

outcomes.title: Pay for Quiet
outcomes.desc: Buy discretion like you buy grain: in bulk and without ceremony.

success.text: Coin disappears into sleeves. Doors close. Conversations end early. The truth remains true, but it becomes unprofitable to repeat, which in some cities is the same as silence.

fail.text: Your coin isn’t enough—or it’s offered to the wrong person. The price rises mid-negotiation, and you feel yourself sliding toward the kind of debt that grows teeth.

outcomes.title: Confess to the Stone
outcomes.desc: Go back. Tell the truth where the vow was made and accept what comes.

success.text: You return to the wind-scoured place and speak plainly. The confession doesn’t erase what you’ve done, but it stops the lie from growing. Some call you a fool. A few call you brave.

fail.text: The truth hits the crowd like ash in the eyes. No one thanks you for it. You leave with your name bruised and the sense that honesty is not the same as safety.

name: The Ring-Law Duel
prompt: They choose a terrace of flat stone where the wind can carry witness to the peaks. Two champions step forward. An elder speaks the old law: a broken vow must be answered—by coin, by confession, or by blood. Eyes turn to you. In one way or another, you started this by being present.

outcomes.title: Fight as Champion
outcomes.desc: Take steel in hand and let the mountain judge your right.

success.text: The duel is a narrow world: breath, balance, and the next heartbeat. You win by inches, and when the other champion yields, the crowd exhales as if they’d been holding their lungs for years.

fail.text: You step wrong, or the other steps better. Pain blooms and the stone rushes up to meet you. They don’t kill you—honor forbids it—but you leave the terrace knowing your body will remember this loss.

outcomes.title: Name the Truth Before Blades
outcomes.desc: Speak plainly. Force the room to look at the real shape of the lie.

success.text: Your words cut cleaner than steel. A few faces shift, then harden into acceptance. The champions hesitate, and in that pause, the elders seize control. Blood is avoided—not forgiven, just postponed in favor of terms.

fail.text: Your truth is met with shouting, then laughter. People don’t want clarity—they want victory. The duel proceeds, and your attempt to shape it becomes another thing they can blame later.

outcomes.title: Present Hidden Proof
outcomes.desc: Reveal the detail you kept back—the one that turns doubt into certainty.

success.text: You lay the proof out like a knife on a table. It’s quiet afterward, the way rooms get when a lie dies. The elders speak, the champions step back, and the duel’s purpose changes: not ‘who is right,’ but ‘how do we live with this.’

fail.text: You show what you have—and it’s not enough. People poke at it until it bleeds uncertainty. You’ve spent your leverage and bought only a harsher mood.

outcomes.title: Rig the Outcome
outcomes.desc: A slip of sand, a shifted footing, a whisper at the right moment.

success.text: You tilt fate without anyone being able to prove it. The ‘right’ champion wins, the crowd cheers, and the world falls back into a story it can stomach. You keep the ugly method as a private possession.

fail.text: Your interference is caught in the corner of someone’s eye. The accusation spreads like flame through dry grass. Whatever the duel’s outcome, your name becomes the stain everyone talks around.

name: The Unbroken Word
prompt: After blood, after ink, after the long night of consequences, there is only what remains: a community trying to decide what ‘honor’ means tomorrow. At the oathstone, a new bowl of water is set. A new ring lies ready. They ask what should be written into the world now—peace, profit, truth, or vengeance.

outcomes.title: Bind a New Oath
outcomes.desc: Tie the loose threads. Make a vow that keeps the next generation from inheriting this wound.

success.text: You speak carefully, choosing words that can survive years. The new vow doesn’t erase the old failure, but it builds a bridge over it. People leave with their shoulders lower, as if they’ve been granted the rare gift of an ending.

fail.text: You try to bind peace, but your voice shakes, and doubt slips in through the cracks. The vow is made anyway, more out of exhaustion than conviction. It may hold. It may not. But at least it exists.

outcomes.title: Take the Bloodprice and Leave
outcomes.desc: Let the locals keep their honor. You’ll keep the profit and the distance.

success.text: You accept payment with a small, careful smile. You will be remembered as necessary, not beloved. On the road away, the coin is warm in your purse and cold in your conscience.

fail.text: The moment you reach for profit, someone calls it what it is. Voices rise. Accusations stick. You leave quickly, but the story follows you, and stories can put a rope around a neck faster than any blade.

outcomes.title: Let the Feud Burn
outcomes.desc: Refuse to mediate. If they want blood, they can spill it without your help.

success.text: You step aside and make it clear you won’t be used as a shield for anyone’s hatred. The decision frees you—and condemns them to their own choices. You leave with your name intact and your hands clean, if not your heart.

fail.text: They don’t let you leave cleanly. Someone takes your refusal as an insult, and the last argument of a feud finds your ribs. Even if you survive, you’ll remember how quickly ‘honor’ turns into violence.

outcomes.title: Speak the Truth to All
outcomes.desc: Name what happened, who profited, and what it cost—out loud, where everyone can hear.

success.text: You lay the story bare. It hurts to hear, which is how you know it’s true. Some faces harden, but others soften, and you sense the future shifting—slightly—toward something less cruel.

fail.text: Truth, in the wrong mouth at the wrong time, becomes ‘slander.’ They turn on you as if you invented the pain instead of describing it. Your words may still matter later—but right now, you pay for them.

name: A Letter of Credit
prompt: In Kestrelbank, bridges cross more than water—they cross obligations. A clerk with ink-stained fingers offers you a folded letter sealed in wax and confidence. “Simple,” they say. “A signature, a witness, a favor. The kind of thing that follows a family like a good name.” You can smell the trap only because it’s wearing perfume.

outcomes.title: Sign as Guarantor
outcomes.desc: Put your name beneath theirs and pretend you believe in clean outcomes.

success.text: Your signature slides into place like a blade into a sheath. The clerk smiles as if you’ve done them a kindness. You receive a ‘courtesy’ purse and a promise that the matter will remain small.

fail.text: The ink smears, the seal cracks, and the clerk’s smile thins. You’ve signed—but clumsily. That means fees, scrutiny, and the sort of ‘assistance’ that always arrives with a bill attached.

outcomes.title: Read the Fine Ink
outcomes.desc: Ask for the ledger, the clause, the precedent—anything that makes the trap visible.

success.text: You read until the clerk’s patience breaks. In the margins, you find the true language: who pays if someone disappears, what heirs inherit when promises rot. You keep a quiet note of it for later.

fail.text: You read and read, but the ink swims. They press you for an answer, and you give one just to end the moment. You leave tired and uneasy, with the certainty that you missed a hook hidden in the wording.

outcomes.title: Forge a Second Copy
outcomes.desc: If paperwork is a weapon, make yourself another blade.

success.text: You produce a twin document—close enough that only a truly careful eye will notice the lie. If anyone tries to tighten the noose later, you’ll have a way to slip it. The clerk’s purse feels lighter in your hand than it should.

fail.text: Your forgery is good, but not invisible. A blot, a wrong fiber, a seal that doesn’t quite match. The kind of mistake that turns a clever scheme into a hunt.

outcomes.title: Walk Away
outcomes.desc: Refuse the letter and the smile attached to it.

success.text: You decline and keep your hands empty. The clerk looks surprised—then amused. In a city built on obligation, refusing a deal is its own kind of statement. People remember it.

fail.text: You refuse, and the clerk laughs too loudly, turning heads. The moment becomes a small public spectacle. You leave with your pride intact, but your name a little bruised.

name: An Audit Summons
prompt: A sealed notice finds you wherever you try to be ordinary. The countinghouse requests your presence—politely, firmly, as if refusal is merely a different kind of agreement. Inside, rows of ledgers sit like sleeping beasts. An auditor looks up and says your name with the calm of a knife laid on a table.

outcomes.title: Open Your Books
outcomes.desc: Answer questions, pay fees, and hope honesty buys you oxygen.

success.text: You endure the questions. You find the right page before they ask for it. It costs you in hours and filing fees, but the auditor’s suspicion cools by a single degree—which in this business is generosity.

fail.text: You answer, but your answers don’t satisfy. A note is made in the margin beside your name. Notes like that become chains when they’re recopied often enough.

outcomes.title: Pay for a Quiet Filing
outcomes.desc: Offer coin and a respectful tone. Let discretion do the work.

success.text: Coin vanishes into a drawer like it was always meant to be there. The auditor’s gaze softens. A ‘clerical error’ is found. The summons becomes a conversation, then a memory.

fail.text: The auditor’s eyes harden. They don’t take the coin. Worse—they make sure you know they could. The implication hangs: they will remember you tried.

outcomes.title: Hide the Numbers
outcomes.desc: Move ink, shift totals, and make the ledger tell a kinder story.

success.text: You slide the truth into a shadow where it can’t be counted. The auditor finds what you want them to find—almost. As you leave, you can feel the city’s paperwork turning, slowly, toward you.

fail.text: A clerk catches a glimpse of what you’ve changed. Their face says nothing, but their pen moves quickly. The room becomes colder, and you realize you are now part of the ledger in the worst way.

outcomes.title: Threaten the Auditor
outcomes.desc: Make it clear that digging too deep can hurt.

success.text: You lean close and let your presence do the speaking. The auditor blinks once, slowly, and sets your file aside. You’ve bought time—nothing more. Time is still worth something.

fail.text: They don’t flinch. They call for a clerk, then another. Suddenly you’re not a threat—you’re a case. The countinghouse has a way of turning anger into paperwork.

name: Terms at Marrowgate
prompt: Marrowgate’s contract court smells of wax, sweat, and damp wool. Disputes are weighed like grain—by witnesses, by precedent, by whose signature holds the sharpest edge. Your matter is called, and suddenly your life is a line item in someone else’s argument.

outcomes.title: Argue Precedent
outcomes.desc: Quote cases, cite clauses, and make your story feel inevitable.

success.text: You speak in the court’s language and watch shoulders relax—this is a story they recognize. The scribe’s pen moves more slowly, which is how you know you’re winning.

fail.text: You cite the wrong precedent and the opposing clerk pounces. The room turns against you not with anger, but with boredom—the worst kind of dismissal.

outcomes.title: Offer Collateral
outcomes.desc: Pay in advance, so the court can pretend it was never personal.

success.text: You swallow pride and place coin on the table. The gesture changes the room’s temperature. People become helpful when the outcome looks profitable for everyone.

fail.text: You offer what you can, and it’s read as desperation. The court accepts—then adds fees. By the time you leave, the number in your head has grown teeth.

outcomes.title: Find the Missing Witness
outcomes.desc: Locate the person who can swear your side is the one worth believing.

success.text: You find the witness in a tavern with a cheap drink and expensive fear. A few quiet words later, they agree to appear. Not for justice—for safety. Still, it helps.

fail.text: The witness is already bought—or already gone. You return empty-handed and feel the court’s patience thin. In a place like this, emptiness is an admission.

outcomes.title: Call Their Bluff
outcomes.desc: Force them to prove their claim, loudly, in front of people who take notes.

success.text: You speak with the certainty of someone who isn’t afraid of questions. The other side falters. A few smiles appear—people love watching a liar sweat under a lamp.

fail.text: You push too hard and become the spectacle. The court doesn’t punish you with chains—it punishes you with contempt. The scribe writes anyway.

name: Night Quay Exchange
prompt: Gilderhaven’s night air tastes of tar and salt. Lanterns swing like pendulums over dark water. A hooded figure waits by a piling, and when they speak your name, it sounds like they’ve been reading it for years. “Ledger problems,” they say. “Ledger solutions.”

outcomes.title: Make the Swap
outcomes.desc: Trade papers in the dark and pretend you’ll never need daylight again.

success.text: A bundle changes hands—heavy with ink and consequence. You walk away with the kind of leverage that can buy silence, and the kind of guilt that can’t.

fail.text: A lantern flares at the worst moment. Someone shouts. Feet run. You escape, but the exchange becomes a story, and stories draw attention like blood draws flies.

outcomes.title: Double-Cross Them
outcomes.desc: Take their papers and their purse. Leave them holding air.

success.text: You move first and don’t stop moving until it’s done. The dock becomes a brief, brutal theater. You leave with extra weight in your pack and fewer illusions about who you are willing to be.

fail.text: They expected treachery. Steel flashes. Pain follows. You stagger away with little gained and a fresh injury that makes every step a reminder.

outcomes.title: Signal the Watch
outcomes.desc: Turn the deal into an arrest and try to come out looking clean.

success.text: Boots arrive fast—too fast to be coincidence. The hooded figure is seized, and for a moment you are ‘helpful.’ Whether the countinghouses believe your purity is another question.

fail.text: Your signal is seen. The hooded figure vanishes, and someone whispers your name into the darkness like a curse. When the watch arrives, they find only you—and your awkward explanations.

outcomes.title: Burn the Evidence
outcomes.desc: Destroy the papers and hope fire is a cleaner judge than ink.

success.text: The flame eats names and numbers. The hooded figure curses and retreats, suddenly less interested in you. You’ve traded leverage for safety—a fair bargain, some nights.

fail.text: The fire spreads too far and too fast. You run, coughing, with smoke in your eyes and your heart hammering like a guilty drum. You survive, but you feel emptied by the effort.

name: The Contract Court
prompt: The contract court convenes with practiced boredom. To them, ruin is routine. Your case is read aloud—dry words that still manage to cut. The clerk asks what remedy you propose, and the room waits to see whether you will pay, plead, or poison someone’s reputation.

outcomes.title: Settle in Coin
outcomes.desc: Buy the ending. Pay until the ink says you are free.

success.text: You pay. It hurts. The clerk stamps the page, and just like that, your disaster becomes ‘resolved.’ In Marrowgate, that is the closest thing to mercy.

fail.text: You pay, but the court finds ‘additional fees.’ The number grows. You leave with the ending purchased but not affordable, a freedom that tastes suspiciously like debt.

outcomes.title: Reveal the Hidden Clause
outcomes.desc: Use what you found in the fine ink to turn their certainty against them.

success.text: You read the clause out loud, slowly, and watch faces change color. The court shifts—subtly, but decisively. A trap is still a trap when the victim notices it first.

fail.text: You present the clause and the other side produces a ‘clarification’ already filed. The court stares at you as if you’ve wasted their time. In Marrowgate, wasting time is a kind of sin.

outcomes.title: Offer a Secret
outcomes.desc: Trade leverage for leniency. In a court like this, truth is currency.

success.text: You lean in and whisper something that makes a scribe pause mid-stroke. The remedy suddenly becomes ‘negotiable.’ The court isn’t kind, but it is practical—and you’ve given it a reason to be practical in your favor.

fail.text: Your secret doesn’t buy what you thought it would. Worse, it leaks. You leave with less leverage and the sense that you’ve just taught the wrong people where your soft parts are.

outcomes.title: Let Them Try You
outcomes.desc: Refuse settlement. Force judgment. Put your life in the court’s hands.

success.text: You stand firm through the questioning and refuse to flinch. The court’s decision is not generous, but it is clear—and clarity is a weapon. You leave with your spine intact.

fail.text: They pick you apart piece by piece, not with malice, but with procedure. When the judgment falls, it falls heavy. The crowd disperses, and you realize you’ve been publicly reduced to a problem on paper.

name: Balance Due
prompt: When the court closes its books, your life doesn’t. The balance remains, in coin or reputation or the attention you attracted. A clerk offers you a final paper to sign—an ending, they promise, if you choose the right kind of ending.

outcomes.title: Pay It Clean
outcomes.desc: End the matter with coin and discipline, even if it hurts.

success.text: You pay the last of it and watch the clerk stamp the page with bored finality. It’s expensive to be ‘clean,’ but the road feels lighter when you don’t expect a summons at every door.

fail.text: You try to pay and come up short. The clerk’s expression doesn’t change, but the paperwork does. A clean ending becomes a debt ending—still an ending, just the kind that follows you.

outcomes.title: Disappear into the Road
outcomes.desc: Leave before the ink dries. Become a rumor instead of a defendant.

success.text: You vanish into the spaces between towns—the unremarkable roads where names dissolve. It costs you supplies and comfort, but it buys you breathing room. For now.

fail.text: A checkpoint. A question. A clerk who recognizes you. The chase begins in earnest, and you realize you didn’t flee a court—you fled an entire system built to find people like you.

outcomes.title: Sell the Debt to Another
outcomes.desc: Shift the burden. Let someone else inherit the problem… for a price.

success.text: You find a buyer for misery. The paper changes hands, and so does responsibility. It’s a cruel kind of cleverness, but cleverness keeps people alive.

fail.text: Your attempt to offload the debt looks like what it is: a con. The buyer smiles, refuses, and later you hear your name spoken with a new edge. You didn’t solve the problem. You advertised it.

outcomes.title: Take a Patron's Mark
outcomes.desc: Accept protection in exchange for service. Trade freedom for stability.

success.text: A hand reaches out from above your station and closes around your problem. In return, your future becomes… guided. It’s safer. It’s narrower. Some people call that a bargain.

fail.text: You reach for protection and find only another set of terms. The ‘patron’ wants too much, too openly. Refusing them feels like refusing a storm. You leave with nothing signed and everything worse.

name: Storm-Locked Lanterns
prompt: The Sable Coast answers travelers the way it answers ships: with weather. A storm pins you against rock and surf until even stubborn pride gives up. A cluster of lanterns ahead promises shelter—an old wayhouse built beside the remains of a drowned abbey. The locals won’t meet your eyes when they mention it. They say the bell still rings below the waves.

outcomes.title: Shelter in the Wayhouse
outcomes.desc: Take the offered roof and ignore the stories for one night.

success.text: You find a dry corner and share warmth with strangers. Outside, the sea roars like an argument. In the night, you wake to a sound that might be wind… or might be something ringing where bells shouldn’t.

fail.text: Sleep comes in scraps. The floor is cold, the air damp, and the storm’s voice never stops. By dawn you’ve survived, but you feel as if you’ve been worn down by a patient hand.

outcomes.title: Ask the Fisher-Folk
outcomes.desc: Pay in respect and questions. Let locals decide what you deserve to know.

success.text: A weathered woman speaks softly: names, dates, a warning not to speak your true name near the surf. It sounds like superstition until she shows you a rosary of rusted keys pulled from the ruins.

fail.text: Your questions land wrong. The locals go quiet, and you realize you’ve treated fear like entertainment. They still point you to shelter, but the kindness is thin.

outcomes.title: Walk the Shoreline Alone
outcomes.desc: Follow the foam line and see what the storm has uncovered.

success.text: Between waves you spot something unnatural: a plank carved with script that the salt should have eaten long ago. When you touch it, the wood feels warmer than it should. You wrap it quickly and pretend your pulse hasn’t changed.

fail.text: The cold gets into your bones. Your clothes cling, your fingers numb, and the storm seems pleased with its work. You return shaking, carrying nothing but the beginning of a sickness.

outcomes.title: Loot the Tidelocked Chapel
outcomes.desc: If the sea has taken offerings, perhaps you can take them back.

success.text: You pry a coffer free and find a handful of old coins, stamped with a face you don’t recognize. When you pocket them, you feel a small wrongness settle over you, like a wet cloak on your shoulders.

fail.text: A beam shifts. The noise carries. When you emerge, someone is already yelling and pointing, and suddenly the storm is no longer your biggest problem.

name: The Salt-Soaked Ledger
prompt: At low tide, the ruins show their teeth: steps descending into water, broken arches, and a silt-choked alcove where a book lies half-buried. The cover is swollen, the pages stuck together—yet the ink hasn’t run. It’s a ledger of names. Some are crossed out. Some are circled. None should still be readable.

outcomes.title: Read the Names Aloud
outcomes.desc: Test superstition with your voice and see what answers.

success.text: You speak the names into the salt air. The sea answers with a long, hollow sound that could be a wave—except the tide is still. Your skin prickles, and you understand why locals avert their gaze when the ruins are mentioned.

fail.text: Halfway through, the air turns colder. A pressure builds behind your eyes, and the names taste like iron. When you stop, you realize you were never reading the book—the book was reading you.

outcomes.title: Carry It Inland
outcomes.desc: Wrap the ledger and bring it somewhere with dry shelves and closed doors.

success.text: You treat it like a sick animal: carefully, without letting it touch bare skin. Inland, people will argue about what it means. Out here, it simply feels wrong.

fail.text: The book is heavier than it looks, and the damp works its way into your clothes. You manage to keep it, but the effort costs you more than you expected.

outcomes.title: Copy It Carefully
outcomes.desc: Transcribe what you can before the sea takes the rest.

success.text: You copy names with a steady hand while the tide breathes at your ankles. The list is stranger than it should be—some names repeat, decades apart, as if the same people keep dying on schedule.

fail.text: The ink smears, the page tears, and you lose the thread. You salvage a few names, but the work leaves you drained, as if you’ve been staring into something that stared back.

outcomes.title: Burn It
outcomes.desc: If it’s a curse, treat it like one: with fire and finality.

success.text: The book takes flame reluctantly, like a living thing that doesn’t want to die. When it finally crumbles, the air feels lighter. Or maybe that’s just your imagination clinging to comfort.

fail.text: The pages char, then go out, damp and stubborn. The smoke smells wrong—sweet, rotten. You cough, and for a moment you hear a bell where there is no bell.

name: The Bell Below
prompt: The storm passes, leaving the world washed and raw. At the ruins, the tide draws back enough to reveal a stairwell descending into darkness and water. Something metal glints below. The bell—if it exists—is down there, waiting in the drowned throat of the abbey.

outcomes.title: Descend at Low Tide
outcomes.desc: Go down now, before the sea decides you’ve had enough.

success.text: You force your way through cold water and broken stone. Your fingers close on a bell-clapper stamped with a symbol you don’t recognize. It feels like it was waiting for a hand—any hand—to claim it.

fail.text: A beam shifts. The world lurches. Stone bites your shoulder, and you claw your way out with blood in the water behind you. Whatever is down there remains down there—but it knows you came.

outcomes.title: Let the Bell Stay Buried
outcomes.desc: Refuse the invitation. Some doors are safer unopened.

success.text: You step back. You breathe. You choose survival over answers. Later, when you try to explain why you didn’t go down, you realize you don’t have words for ‘it felt like the sea was watching.’

fail.text: You turn away—and trip. Your hand plunges into a puddle black with silt, and for an instant you see a face staring up from the water: yours, but older, and smiling. You jerk back, heart hammering.

outcomes.title: Search for a Safer Entrance
outcomes.desc: Circle the ruins, looking for a dry way in.

success.text: You find a crack in the stonework where the water drains. Inside, the abbey smells of old incense and dead salt. You come away with a small, undeniable truth: something here was meant to be remembered.

fail.text: You spend hours in damp wind, soaking through. The chill settles into your chest like a tenant. You learn nothing except how quickly the sea can make a person sick.

outcomes.title: Send Someone Else
outcomes.desc: Offer coin and confidence to a desperate soul and let them take the risk.

success.text: You hire hands and keep your own dry. They come back shaken, clutching a scrap of metal and refusing to speak of what they saw. You pay extra to make sure their silence stays permanent.

fail.text: They don’t return. The locals look at you like you’re the storm itself. You still have your life, but you feel its weight shift—heavier, uglier.

name: Ink and Salt
prompt: In Gloambridge, the air smells of paper and candle wax. An ink-stained archivist listens to your story without blinking. When you show them what you found, their hands tremble—just once. “Some things,” they say, “are meant to be shelved. Some are meant to be buried. The difference is who gets to decide.”

outcomes.title: Sell the Find
outcomes.desc: Take coin now and let someone else carry the meaning.

success.text: The archivist pays more than seems reasonable. You walk out richer and lighter, as if you’ve traded a weight from your soul for a weight in your purse.

fail.text: Your price is too bold. The archivist’s expression cools. They still offer coin, but less—and the story spreads that you tried to profit from the dead.

outcomes.title: Donate It for Safekeeping
outcomes.desc: Hand it over and demand only that it be protected from politics and thieves.

success.text: The archivist swears a careful promise and seals the find in oilcloth. You don’t know if you’ve done the right thing—but you’ve done a thing that will outlast you, and that matters.

fail.text: They agree… with too many conditions. Your ‘donation’ becomes a negotiation, and you realize you’ve traded certainty for bureaucracy. Still, it’s out of your hands now.

outcomes.title: Hide It Yourself
outcomes.desc: Keep the object and the story. Knowledge is safest under your own roof.

success.text: You leave with it wrapped tight and your head full of plans. If it’s valuable, it’s valuable to you first. The archivist watches you go with a look that might be pity.

fail.text: Someone follows you from the archive steps. By the time you notice, it’s too late: your secret has become someone else’s opportunity.

outcomes.title: Refuse and Leave
outcomes.desc: Walk away from scholars, sellers, and the whole hungry world.

success.text: You take your leave with a curt nod and no promises. The archivist doesn’t stop you. Outside, the street feels louder than it should, as if the world senses you’re carrying something it wants.

fail.text: You leave quickly, too quickly. The fear follows you, and by nightfall you’re exhausted from listening for footsteps that may or may not be there.

name: Salt Dreams
prompt: After the ruins, sleep becomes shallow. You dream of bells ringing underwater, of names written on your skin in wet ink. Sometimes you wake with salt on your tongue. Sometimes you wake with the certainty that something is standing at the edge of your room, listening for you to say its name.

outcomes.title: Seek a Candle Ward
outcomes.desc: Find a hospice, light a candle, and beg for cleansing rites.

success.text: You endure bitter smoke, cold water, and a long vigil. The dreams don’t vanish, but they loosen—like a knot that’s been worked at carefully. For the first time in days, you breathe without tasting the sea.

fail.text: You sit through the vigil until your eyes burn. The candle sputters and dies at the worst moment, and the attendants exchange uneasy glances. They won’t say ‘curse.’ They don’t need to.

outcomes.title: Consult a Scholar of Old Things
outcomes.desc: Trade sleep for answers. If it has a name, it can be negotiated with.

success.text: You learn words that feel sharp in the mouth and symbols that make the page itch. Understanding doesn’t free you—but it gives you leverage, and leverage is a kind of safety.

fail.text: The scholar’s eyes widen at what you describe. They refuse to touch your notes. When you insist, their fear turns to anger. You leave with less help than you wanted and more dread than you arrived with.

outcomes.title: Appease the Sea
outcomes.desc: Return to the coast with an offering and a careful prayer.

success.text: You leave an offering where the foam line turns back. The wind eases. For one night, the dreams soften. It’s not victory, but it’s negotiation—and negotiation is how most people survive the gods they don’t believe in.

fail.text: The offering is taken by a wave that hits like a slap. The sea gives no answer except more salt. When you get home, the dreams return with sharper teeth.

outcomes.title: Embrace the Mark
outcomes.desc: Stop running. If something wants you, make it pay for the privilege.

success.text: You lean into the wrongness and feel the world bend slightly to accommodate it. Doors open easier. People look away at the right moments. It’s useful—and that usefulness feels like a bargain you didn’t read before signing.

fail.text: You try to wield the thing in you and discover it was never yours to command. The backlash is social before it’s supernatural: rumors, fear, and the wrong kind of attention.

name: The Abbey Remembers
prompt: Dawn at the Sable Coast is gray and honest. The ruins sit half-submerged, patient as a grave. Whatever you took—ledger, clapper, name—still matters. You can feel it in the way your dreams cling, or in the way strangers look at you like you’ve brought the tide indoors. If the abbey remembers, you must decide what it will remember you as.

outcomes.title: Return It to the Sea
outcomes.desc: Offer back what was taken and accept that some stories should sink.

success.text: You wade into the cold and let the object go. The water takes it without drama. Later, you realize your chest feels lighter, as if a hand finally unclenched.

fail.text: You try to return it, but the wave that takes it feels… deliberate. The cold bites deeper than it should. You leave shivering, not sure if you offered restitution or simply fed something hungry.

outcomes.title: Keep It Hidden
outcomes.desc: Seal it away. Let the world forget while you remain its only witness.

success.text: You wrap the object, lock it, bury it, and mark the spot in memory. A private inheritance. It feels powerful in the way dangerous things often do.

fail.text: You hide it—and immediately sense you haven’t truly hidden anything. The dreams sharpen. The wrongness settles deeper. Some things don’t stay put just because you ask them to.

outcomes.title: Make It Public
outcomes.desc: Tell the story out loud, in daylight, where liars can be contradicted.

success.text: People listen, then argue, then listen harder. The story escapes your hands and becomes a thing the world must deal with. That is terrifying. That is also a kind of protection.

fail.text: The crowd laughs first, then grows uneasy, then turns mean. They call you a thief, a liar, a blasphemer. By the end, you’ve turned a mystery into a target painted on your back.

outcomes.title: Sell It in the Night
outcomes.desc: Find a buyer who doesn’t ask questions, and take coin for consequences.

success.text: The sale happens in a place without windows. The buyer’s hands are too clean. They pay well. As you leave, you wonder whether you’ve rid yourself of danger—or delivered it into sharper hands.

fail.text: The buyer tries to take it without paying. The argument becomes physical, then loud, then public. You escape with your life and the certainty that the story will not stay quiet.
